Belgia. 1591 7 May To M
r
Bodly
Belgia: 1591: May.
M
r
Bodeley
S
r
. Uppon the coming hether of
Capteine Vanderbronke
, w
th
S
r
Robert Sidneies
letters to mee declaring a devise of his for
the surprising of the Towne of
Dunkirke,
whearein having had
severall Conferences w
th
him, and at sondrie times acquainted hir
Ma
tie
thearew
th
, she conceiving both go od likelood of the Action
if soe be the same maie be carried w
th
secrecie, w
ch
might have
been much better done, if the same cowld have been kept from the
knowledge either of the
Counte Maurice
, or the
States,
as she findeth
it cannot be from the Counte, by reason the Enterprise is to be
attempted by Sea, hath been pleased that S
r
Robart Sidneie should
acquaint the Counte Maurice w
th
the matter, and that yowe showld
aswell uppon conference w
th
this Capteine, whoe semeth to deale
vearie frankelie, and to adventure himself in the discoverie of the
place before the matter be attempted, debate fullie w
th
him all
thinges neadefull to be conseved both of the manner and meanes
for the achevinge of this Enterprise: And also hir Ma
tie
would
have yowe to renewe a former offer made to yowe of like purpose
in as secrett manner as maie be, so that the place maie be
newlie renewed to discover whether theare be ane alteration of
the place to be attempted since that offer was made, for I finde in
this Capteine soe honest a disposic
o
n, and desire to have the thinge
effected, as he can be content to have yt taken in hand by anie
other devise aswell as his owne; and if both maie be fownde
fesible, both maie be attempted at one time. This is in effect all
that I am directed by hir Ma
tie
to write to yowe hearein seming
that when thing
shall be browght to a resoluc
o
n, uppon the
explorac
o
n of all matters, hir Ma
tie
would first be advertised
theareof before anie thinge be attempted, And bicawse the Capteine
himself & S
r
Robart Sidneie will more perticulerlye require
yowe hearew
th
, I will finishe my letter.
And so most hartelie
bid yowe farewell./ From Westm
r
the seaventh of
Maye
1591
.
Yo
r
assured Lovinge frend William Burghley
